1.text: Lo, mine eye hath seen all this, Mine ear hath heard and understood it.

2.text: What ye know, do I know also; I am not inferior unto you.

3.text: Notwithstanding I would speak to the Almighty, And I desire to reason with God.

4.text: But ye are plasterers of lies, Ye are all physicians of no value.

5.text: Oh that ye would altogether hold your peace! And it would be your wisdom.

6.text: Hear now my reasoning, And hearken to the pleadings of my lips.

7.text: Will ye speak unrighteously for God, And talk deceitfully for Him?

8.text: Will ye show Him favour? Will ye contend for God?

9.text: Would it be good that He should search you out? Or as one mocketh a man, will ye mock Him?

10.text: He will surely reprove you, If ye do secretly show favour.

11.text: Shall not His majesty terrify you, And His dread fall upon you?

12.text: Your memorials shall be like unto ashes, Your eminences to eminences of clay.

13.text: Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, And let come on me what will.

14.text: Wherefore? I will take my flesh in my teeth, And put my life in my hand.

15.text: Though He slay me, yet will I trust in Him; But I will argue my ways before Him.

16.text: This also shall be my salvation, That a hypocrite cannot come before Him.

17.text: Hear diligently my speech, And let my declaration be in your ears.

18.text: Behold now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shall be justified.

19.text: Who is he that will contend with me? For then would I hold my peace and die.

20.text: Only do not two things unto me, Then will I not hide myself from Thee:

21.text: Withdraw Thy hand far from me; And let not Thy terror make me afraid.

22.text: Then call Thou, and I will answer; Or let me speak, and answer Thou me.

23.text: How many are mine iniquities and sins? Make me to know my transgression and my sin.

24.text: Wherefore hidest Thou Thy face, And holdest me for Thine enemy?

25.text: Wilt Thou harass a driven leaf? And wilt Thou pursue the dry stubble?

26.text: That Thou shouldest write bitter things against me, And make me to inherit the iniquities of my youth.

27.text: Thou puttest my feet also in the stocks, And lookest narrowly unto all my paths; Thou drawest Thee a line about the soles of my feet;

28.text: Though I am like a wine-skin that consumeth, Like a garment that is moth-eaten.
